revisions.rev:
{{prose|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Company | company_name = Psystar Corporation | company_logo = [[Image:Psystarlogo.png|||Psystar Logo]] | location_city = 10475 NW 28th Street, [[Doral, Florida]] | location_country = USA | industry = {{nowrap begin}}[[Computer hardware]]{{Â·}} [[Computer software]]{{wrap}}[[Consumer electronics]]{{nowrap end}} }} '''Psystar Corporation''' was a [[Miami, Florida]] based company which sold "Open Computers". These [[computers]], first announced in April 2008, had the option to be pre-installed with [[Mac OS X Leopard]], making them the first commercially distributed [[OSx86|"hackintosh" computers]].<ref>[http://www.crn.com/hardware/207200440 Psystar Releases Mac Clone]</ref> In November 2009, a U.S. Federal District Court ruled Psystar violated [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] copyrights in doing so.<ref>[http://www.groklaw.net/pdf2/Psystar-214.pdf Order Re Cross Motions for Summary Judgement], ''Apple v. Psystar,'' No. C 08-03251 WHA</ref>
== Rebel EFI == Rebel EFI was a product from Psystar that helped users to install Mac OS X on "regular" x86 computers. A trial version was free of charge, but the full version cost money. It has been alleged that Rebel EFI was not an original work of Psystar, but was based on an open source program called boot-132.<ref>[http://www.osnews.com/comments/22402 OSNews.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Early concerns ==
Early efforts to research Psystar shortly after their announcement of a Mac clone in April 2008 resulted in questions regarding the companyâs very existence and just how legitimate they were.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://government.zdnet.com/?p=3758 |title=Psystar: Hoax or fraud? |accessdate=Sept 14, 2008 |work=[[ZDNet Government]] |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |date=2008-04-16 |author=Koman, Richard }}</ref><ref name= 2008-04-17 >{{cite web |url=http://government.zdnet.com/?p=3761 |title=Psystar mystery adds up to phishing scam |accessdate=Sept 14, 2008 |work=[[ZDNet Government]] |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |date=2008-04-17 |author=Koman, Richard }}</ref> Several addresses were provided (five in four days) and Psystar was taking credit card numbers but not processing them because their processing company, Powerpay, had revoked Psystarâs account "for three primary reasons: product/services not as represented in application, sales volumes grossly exceeded, no address verification utilized";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://government.zdnet.com/?p=3763 |title=PowerPay statement on Psystar |accessdate=December 12, 2009 |publisher=ZDNet Government |date=2008-04-17 |author= Koman, Richard}}</ref> and there were claims that their website had malware on it.<ref name=2008-04-17 /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetechherald.com/article.php/200816/749/Psystar-and-its-Mac-clone-accused-of-being-Phishing-scam |title=Psystar and its Mac clone accused of being Phishing scam |accessdate=Sept 14, 2008 |publisher=The Tech Herald |date=2008-04-18 |author= Smith, Stevie}}</ref>
The developers of the [[OSx86]] Project claimed that Psystar did not get permission to use their code and then reworked their license so that it specifically forbids commercial usage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2008/04/16/osx86-project-not-too-happy-with-psystar-either/ |title=OSx86 Project not too happy with Psystar either |accessdate=Sept 17, 2008 |publisher=Engadge |date=2008-04-16 |author= Patel, Nilay}}</ref>
As part of Appleâs discovery process it was revealed that in 2008 Psystar presented a slide presentation in hope of raising $24 million from investors. âUnder its conservative projections, Psystar told investors it would sell 70,000 computers in 2009, 470,000 systems in 2010, and 1.45 million machines in 2011. The firmâs aggressive growth model, however, put those numbers at 130,000, 1.87 million, and 12 million during 2009, 2010, and 2011, respectively.â<ref name=2009-11-25>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9141473/Psystar_promised_investors_huge_clone_sales |title=OSx86 Psystar promised investors huge clone sales; But clone maker sold just 768 systems, says Appleâs economist |accessdate=November 27, 2009|publisher=Computerworld |date=2009-11-25 |author= Keizer, Gregg}}</ref>
However the reality was quite different. â âPsystar produced incomplete financial records,â Dr. Matthew Lynde, who works as an economics consultant for Cornerstone Research, said in a declaration during trial. After digging through invoices, purchase orders and other documents, Lynde was able to pinpoint only 768 sales of machines with Mac OS X pre-installed. Psystar did not challenge Lynde in his analysis of financial records.<ref name=2009-11-25/>
== Legal issues == {{prose|section|date=August 2010}} The [[end-user license agreement]] for [http://images.apple.com/legal/sla/docs/macosx105.pdf Mac OS X] forbids third-party installations of Mac OS X, and Psystar's Mac clone is in violation of that agreement.<ref name="IW">{{cite web |url=http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2008/04/mac_clone_maker.html |title=Mac Clone Maker Psystar Vows To Challenge Apple EULA |accessdate=19 November 2008 |work=[[InformationWeek|InformationWeek Blog]] |publisher=[[United Business Media]] |date=2008-04-14 |author=McDougall, Paul }}</ref> However, Psystar argues that Apple's prohibition against third-party installations will not hold up in court: "What if [[Honda]] said that, after you buy their car, you could only drive it on the roads they said you could?"<ref name="IW"/> Psystar says it will continue to sell the Open system, adding "We're not breaking any laws."<ref name="IW"/>
On July 3, 2008, Apple filed a lawsuit against Psystar in the [[United States district court|District Court]] of [[Northern California]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-9991572-56.html |title=Apple sues clone maker Psystar |accessdate=19 November 2008 |work=[[CNET News]] |publisher=[[CBS Corporation]] |date=2008-07-15 |author=Fried, Ina }}</ref>
On August 28, 2008, Psystar Corporation responded to Apple's claims of copyright infringement, and also countersued Apple for [[anti-competitive practices]], [[Monopoly|monopolistic behavior]], and [[copyright misuse]].<ref>[http://www.psystar.com/apple_v_psystar_answer_a_counterclaim_filed.html Psystar: Apple v. Psystar - Answer & Counterclaim Filed]</ref><ref>[http://www.itworld.com/hardware/56947/psystar-beats-apple-blu-ray-os-x-computer Psystar beats Apple to Blu-ray on OS X computer]</ref> This countersuit was dismissed on November 18, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13579_3-10101581-37.html |title=Psystar antitrust claim against Apple dismissed |accessdate=19 November 2008 |work=[[CNET News]] |publisher=[[CBS Corporation]] |date=2008-11-18 |author=Krazit, Tom }}</ref>
On November 27, 2008, Apple claimed "Psystar violated the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) by dodging copy-protection technologies Apple uses to protect Mac OS X. "Apple employs technological protection measures that effectively control access to Apple's copyrighted works," the revised complaint read. "Defendant has illegally circumvented Apple's technological copyright-protection measures. [...] Specifically, Apple charged Psystar with acquiring or creating "code" that "avoids, bypasses, removes, descrambles, decrypts, deactivates or impairs a technological protection measure without Apple's authority for the purpose of gaining unauthorized access to Apple's copyrighted works."<ref>{{cite web|last=Keizer |first=Gregg |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9121798/Apple_adds_DMCA_charge_to_lawsuit_against_Psystar |title=Apple adds DMCA charge to lawsuit against Psystar: It accuses clone maker of breaking Mac OS copy-protection scheme |publisher=computerworld.com |date=November 30, 2008 |accessdate=2009-10-07}}</ref> This brief revealed that Apple uses methods it considers protected by the [[DMCA]] to prevent MacOS X from being installed on non-Apple hardware.
On December 22, 2008, Psystar opened the claim that Apple "is prohibited from bringing action against Psystar for the alleged infringement of one or more of the plaintiff's copyrights for failure to register said copyrights with the copyright office as required" by law.<ref>[http://www.informationweek.com/news/hardware/mac/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=212501673 Apple Failed To Copyright Mac OS X, Psystar Claims]</ref>
On February 5, 2009, Psystar won a round as a modified abuse of copyright claim against Apple under Judge William Alsup, opening the door to a potential nullification of the Apple-only hardware rule in Apple's EULA.<ref>{{cite web|last=Keizer |first=Gregg |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9127579/Mac_clone_maker_wins_legal_round_against_Apple |title=Mac clone maker wins legal round against Apple: Psystar can argue Apple abused copyright laws, judge rules |publisher=computerworld.com |date=February 8, 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-06}}</ref>
In April 2009, Apple alleged that Psystar was withholding financial information relating to their company and that "at the deposition regarding Psystarâs revenues, profits, assets, and liabilities (including investors, lenders, or other sources of financial support), taken on March 20, 2009, Psystarâs CEO and founder Rudy Pedraza, the person designated by Psystar to testify on this topic, would not answer basic questions about Psystarâs financials." <ref> {{cite web|last=Jade |first=Kasper |url=http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/05/01/apple_says_psystar_holding_back_info_in_mac_clone_legal_case.html |title=Apple says Psystar holding back info in Mac clone legal case |publisher=[[AppleInsider]] |date=May 1, 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-06}}</ref> Psystar countered that they have never produced monthly, quarterly, or yearly statements, that they lost some documents when moving premises, and that they have produced the requested information where available.<ref>[http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/05/08/psystar_claims_apple_asking_for_non_existent_redundant_info.html Psystar claims Apple asking for non-existent, redundant info], [[AppleInsider]]</ref>
On May 26, 2009, Psystar filed for Chapter 11 [[bankruptcy]]. Regardless, the company continued to sell their computers with Apple's [[Mac OS X]] installed on them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.macobserver.com/tmo/article/psystar_files_bankruptcy_stalls_apples_case/ |title=Psystar Files Bankruptcy, Stalls Appleâs Case |accessdate=26 May 2009 |work=[[TMO Scoop]] |publisher=[[The Mac Observer, Inc]] |date=2009-05-26 |author=Gamet, Jeff }}</ref> Apple challenged that Psystar was using Chapter 11 bankruptcy to stall the case, and in June 2009, the court lifted the stay on Apple's lawsuit.
On July 2, 2009, Psystar announced that they would emerge from Chapter 11 protection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://psystar.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/r/6A585E4F43BB4E5B/7576075A56BBAC6D9A8E73400EDACAB4 |title=Chapter 11, exit stage right |accessdate=Sept 12, 2009 |work=Psystar Meta Update |publisher=Psystar |date= |author=}}</ref>
As of August 12, 2009, debtor Psystar's bankruptcy was dismissed with prejudice with stipulations by Florida Judge Mark that no Chapter 11 bankruptcy can be filed for 12 months and that there will be no stay of any pending cases if Psystar seeks Chapter 7 bankruptcy. "One effect of the judge's orders is that Psystar won't be able to use bankruptcy as a stall tactic against Appleâthat trial is set to begin in January. But the other effect of the order is that Psystar can be sued by its creditors. 'All of Psystar's creditors are now free to sue in any court of competent jurisdiction to get their debts paid,' an attorney familiar with bankruptcy told The Mac Observer. That includes Apple, which Psystar may owe for copies of Mac OS X it bought from the company."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2009/08/psystar-bankruptcy-dismissed-out-of-the-frying-pan-into-the-fryer.ars |title=Psystar bankruptcy dismissed: out of the frying pan, into the fryer |accessdate=Sept 13, 2009 |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2009-08-12 |author=Foresman, Chris}}</ref>
On August 20, 2009, California Judge Alsup ordered Psystar to pay $5,000 of Apple's legal fees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2009/09/psystar-fined-5k-files-snow-leopard-suit-in-florida.ars |title=Psystar, fined $5K, files Snow Leopard suit in Florida |accessdate=Sept 12, 2009 |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2009-09-01 |author=Foresman, Chris}}</ref>
On October 8, 2009, the court ruled that Psystar was not entitled to Appleâs profit margin data. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edibleapple.com/court-rules-that-psystar-is-not-entitled-to-apples-profit-margin-data/ |title=Court rules that Psystar is not entitled to Appleâs profit margin data |accessdate=Sept 12, 2009 |publisher=[[Edible Apple]] |date=2009-09-01 |author=}}</ref>
On November 13, 2009, the court granted Apple's motion for summary judgement and found Apple's copyrights were violated as well as the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) when Psystar installed Apple's operating system on non-Apple computers. A hearing on remedies was set for December 14.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://brainstormtech.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2009/11/14/apple-wins-clone-suit/ |title=Apple wins clone suit |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |publisher=[[CNN Money]] |date=2009-11-14 |author=Elmer-DeWitt, Philip}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/182218/Apple_Wins_Court_Victory_Over_Mac_Clone_Maker_Psystar.html?tk=rss_news |title=Apple Wins Court Victory Over Mac Clone Maker Psystar |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |publisher=[[Pc World]] |date=2009-11-15 |author=Keizer, Greg}}</ref>
On December 1, 2009, Psystar agreed to pay Apple $2.7 million for copyright infringement, breach of contract, violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, additional damages and attorneys fees in the California lawsuit. The payments were deferred until all Psystar's appeals are exhausted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/12/01/psystar_agrees_to_pay_apple_1_3m_in_settlement.html|title=Psystar agrees to pay Apple $2.7M in settlement |accessdate=December 1, 2009 |publisher=[[AppleInsider]] |date=2009-12-01 |author=Hughes, Neil}}</ref>
On December 15, 2009, the judge in the California action issued a permanent injunction barring Psystar from manufacturing, distributing, or assisting anyone with any sort of device or technology "that is primarily designed or produced for the purpose of circumventing a technological measure". The ruling applies to all current and future versions of Mac OS X and Judge Alsup made it clear that "Psystar will be selling Rebel EFI at its peril, and risks finding itself held in contempt if its new venture falls within the scope of the injunction."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2009/12/psystar-gets-permanent-injunction-legal-warning-from-judge.ars|title=Psystar gets permanent injunction, legal warning from judge |accessdate=December 16, 2009 |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2009-12-16 |author=Foresman, Chris}}</ref> The ruling also requires Psystar to destroy all of its equipment and material that it used in the circumvention of Apple technologies by December 31.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.groklaw.net/article.php?story=20091215225827172 |title= Apple wins total, permanent injunction against Psystar |date= December 15, 2009 }}</ref>
On January 16, 2010, Psystar announced that they would be appealing the lawsuit put in place on December 15.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.macobserver.com/tmo/article/psystar_officially_files_notice_of_appeal_in_apple_lawsuit/ | title=Psystar Officially Files Notice of Appeal in Apple Lawsuit | date=2010-01-15 | author=Bryan Chaffin | publisher=The Mac Observer | accessdate=2010-02-05}} </ref>
As of August, 2010, Psystar's [http://psystar.com/ web site], [http://store.psystar.com/ store], and [http://cdn.psystar.com/ content delivery network] are unreachable.
